prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: B7 continuum and 12CO 3-2, SiO 8-7 snapshot
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: This is a snapshot survey to detect disks and outflows, and quantify the multiplicity of the cores and protostars in a statistically significant sample. We aim to detect any centrally condensed, high density structure in the cores we can associate with a disk, and measure the range of masses. We use a correlator set up to obtain the continuum, the 12CO and the SiO lines using 4 wideband spectral windows. We have chosen the single polarization setup in order to obtain good velocity reoslution. We can then resolve the structure at the base of any young flows associated with the disk, and provide constraints on the age of the flows.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
The cores have submillimetre fluxes from single dish observations at 15" resolution from 120 mJy to 2400 mJy. In the embedded Class 0 phase, the envelope dominates the mass of the system, with a disk to envelope mass ratio of 1% to 10%. Class 0 disks have been observed at high resolution (with CARMA and the SMA) to have masses of a few times 0.01 to 0.1 solar masses. We estimate integrated fluxes from the disk, where present, of 50 to 100 mJy. With expected peak fluxes of 5 to 100 mJy/beam, we therefore require a 1sigma rms of 0.3 mJy in order to detect the disk, or equivalent compact high-density structure, in Band 7. This will allow us to detect unresolved disk masses in the ALMA beam down to 0.01 solar masses (assuming a dust temperature of 30K, and a mass opacity of the gas and dust of 0.01 cm sq./g), with a signal to noise ratio of at least 4. Assuming similar intensities, and that sources remain unresolved in the ALMA beam, this will give us a signal to noise ratio of a few to a few tens on our prestellar cores.
The 31 cores selected as targets for this observing programme have a median core diameter of 9000 AU by 5000 AU. Since NGC2068 is at a distance of 400 pc, the ALMA Band 7 FOV of 18" is equivalent to 7200 AU, a similar size to our target cores. The previously published target cores were observed with a 15" beam, and the reported sizes are only marginally resolved. Much of the emission within the core arises from the extended envelope, which ALMA will resolve out, leaving only the highly compact disk-like structures that we wish to detect. Since the expected core sizes are a good match to the ALMA Band 7 FOV, we will also be able to detect any evidence of fragmentation or multiplicity within the core. The disks we expect many of the cores to contain will be be at most marginally resolved at the requested 0.2" resolution of ALMA Band 7. The synthesised beam size of 0.2" equates to 80 AU at a distance of 400pc: we expect the bulk of the dust emission to arise in the high-density disk, which have a typical diameter of 100 AU.
Two spectral windows will be used to observe the 12CO 3-2 line at 345.79599 GHz and the SiO 8-7 line at 347.67099 GHz. The remaining 2 spectral windows will be used to detect the continuum with the widest possible bandwidth. The velocity resolution of 0.42km/s is sufficient to detect the presence of any high velocity emission due to outflow activity through the use of position velocity diagrams in CO3-2 and SiO 8-7. The low velocity flows may produce emission accelerated by only a few km/s, in relatively compact lobes, which are also best visualised through position velocity diagrams. We require the 0.42km/s spectral resolution observations in order to investigate the kinematics of the outflowing gas around our targets. Our time requirements are driven by the continuum observations. With expected line fluxes in the outflow wings of 0.5K to a few K, we will detect any high velocity gas with signal to noise ratios of >5.
Since our sources are all in the same field and can use the same calibrators, we request that the observations of the sources are interleaved, in order to maximise the uv-coverage of these observations.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: We propose continuum, 12CO and SiO molecular line observations of the NGC2068 protocluster, to measure multiplicity and evolutionary phase of fragmented components within the inner 1000 AU of the cores. We will observe the structure of ambient and high velocity gas flows near disk boundaries, assessing how material is accreted and ejected from the large-scale envelope and disk. CO is the ideal outflow tracer, and the presence of high velocity wings can be used to assign protostellar status to a core fragment, with the outflow opening angle constraining the age of the flow. SiO traces active regions, where the youngest shocks from jets impact high density regions, highlighting the location of accretion hotspots within the system. The core sample has a wide range of evolutionary phases, allowing us to determine when material appears in a disk during core collapse, and the onset of sub-core fragmentation on scales of 100 AU. The NGC2068 protocluster is embedded in an older T Tauri population, whose disk fraction, age and multiplicity is well-characterised. NGC2068 provides a unique opportunity to compare two star forming populations of different ages arising in the same environment
prp:ObsProposal.prp:previousProposals: 2012.1.00071.S, Snapshot survey of disks and multiplicity in NGC2068, J V Buckle
